key_points: Vice President Kamala Harris is set to chair the National Space Council, continuing its operation under the Biden administration.
Harris announced her new role in a tweet, expressing honor in leading the Council and emphasizing America's achievements in space.
The Vice President aims to focus the Council on STEM education, cybersecurity, commercial space activity, diversity, and peaceful space norms.
The National Space Council was previously led by Vice President Mike Pence during the Trump administration, which had revived the council in 2017.
The council's operation will continue under the executive order from 2017, with an ongoing review for potential changes.
The council assists the President in forming national space policies and strategies, balancing civil, commercial, and national security space activities.
An official highlighted Harris' approach to focus on work rather than big displays, differing from Pence's tenure.
Harris has other significant responsibilities, including diplomatic efforts in the Northern Triangle and expanding broadband access.
Harris will swear in the newly confirmed NASA administrator Bill Nelson.
There's no set date for the National Space Council's first meeting under Harris, but she will begin her duties soon.
